ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments:
The course focuses on introducing calculus at a slower pace. Main topics include limit definition of the derivative; simply derivative rules (excluding chain rule, which is MATH 111); generating graphs from equations; f, f', and f'' graph relationships; simple derivative applications and optimization; and the other elements that get you to these things. It's similar to the first part of AP Calculus AB and adds optimization. 

I took AP Calculus AB several years ago and vaguely remembered a lot of the stuff but definitely had to relearn it. They make an effort in the course, or at least my instructor (John Hall!), to explain the inner-workings of the math, which was great for me because I was able to think a lot more critically about the math in general.
I have stronger algebra skills and I have many more strategies at hand to solve the same type of problems.
The course built a strong foundation of mathematical skills and provided an introduction to calculus.

New concepts in Math 110 that I personally learned that were different from AP Calc AP in high school was linearization and linear approximation. I had not talked about those concepts as well as invertible functions and the emphasis on rational functions. I am simply not a good math student.
Community College Calc 1 and Statistics
I learned about the importance of not just absorbing information, but being able to apply it in my own way to fully understand it

I developed a knowledge about solving derivatives and limits using algebraic concepts I knew before and new calculus concepts I was taught. This course taught me how to visualize concepts and really understand the reasoning behind the math, not just the steps/equation.
I've learned more about my own study skills and habits, as well as critical thinking skills.
Better quantitative skills.
I learned pre-calculus and a little bit of calculus. I also relearned algebra.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: John Hall.

Weaknesses: The course time commitment is just very substantial. A typical week consists of a pset, two 75 minute lectures, a 90 minute mandatory workshop with a ULA, and two (short, frankly, but still) pre-class prep things. There are also four concept checks during the semester and an Algebra Gateway (which is pass/fail, repeat until you pass). It was definitely very useful but it was a lot more than I wanted it to be because I took this as a QR credit.
There are many resources and people to refer to ask for help and they are very patient. However, I do believe there are many little tasks like workshops,

The course gave a slower paced approach to mathematics and took care to nurture the foundation of mathematical knowledge of students from various backgrounds. However, I do not think that my level of understanding or engagement with the course was reflected in my grade. The grading of exams tends to be confusing and harsh. Practice material provided for exams were from previous course directors who took a different approach to the course. This made studying for exams difficult and the practice material often heavily varied from the actual exams. I would recommend provided better practice material, especially considering how heavily exams count toward the course. I would also recommend standardizing notes and classroom materials as they varied heavily from instructor to instructor.

One main strength of Math 110 is the pacing. I do sometimes wish we could get more worksheets that work on specific mathematical topics, since the p-set covers a broader range of concepts.
As a student that dropped into Math 110 at the middle mark of the semester, one main difference that I can point out between Math 110/111 and Math 112 is that there are weekly workshops to attend and extra homework in Canvas on top of the p-sets. I personally did not even know about the extra Canvas homework until several weeks later. I did enjoy the workshops because we get more practice with TA that can explain the concepts well. 

I do want to mention that there were surprisingly no graphs on the final exam, yet there are numerous graphs that we had to graph on the psets. After taking the final, I feel that they make the questions on the exams harder, to the point that even if you are familiar with the content that you are being asked about, it is presented in a way I am not familiar with. It is just eccentric how the questions on the exams are designed verses the questions we practice weekly.
More technical questions in class similar to the problem sets.

Strengths:

Office hour support
Gateways to consolidate content
Professor support

Weakness:

Maybe more gateways to further test knowledge

This course was a good entry into calculus because it reviewed noteworthy concepts from prior math classes I've taken. However, I felt like this course lacked the in-class practice and explanation of all concepts. Some class periods felt a little redundant and not useful compared to what we were solving for the problem sets.

Every week, it felt like the things we learned in class weren't the same as what we saw on worksheets. While I understand now this was purposeful, I wish there has been more guidance in the beginning to understand this. There was, alot I didn't know around how courses worked, and what the expectations were.there was a learning curve that held back me back.

Strengths - great professor. Excellent teaching. Excellent ULAs. 
Weaknesses - PSETs are sometimes quite long though not often.
The class is very thorough, and I liked that all the topics were connected and cumulative.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If you need a slower, more intensive pace, then yes (especially if John Hall is teaching!). Otherwise take 112 so you can do 110/111 in one semester. If you want to take this as a QR, do not.
Yes, I would especially recommend this course to someone who did not take a math course recently and would like to refresh their skills and ease into calculus topics.

If you need math, then take it. However I didnt need it for anything and completely regretted my time in the course. If you have never taken calculus before this will be hard due to the pace and the way that concepts are explained. I would never take this again.

I would recommend this to another student due to the valuable ways that it contributed to furthering my mathematical knowledge. However, students need to be prepared to contribute a large amount of time to the course.

I would definitely recommend Math 110 to another student as a better alternative to Math 112 (especially if taking Math 110 & 111 will not put them too far behind). I originally was in Math 112, bu decided to drop down a level into Math 110/111, which was definitely the right choice. For a concept such as Calculus, pacing truly does matter, and I like that Math 110 did not rush through complex topics as much as 112 did. Math 110 is also more beginner-friendly, which is definitely a plus.
Yes, it is well taught.
Yes! Its a great way for students who dont have as strong a background in calculus than others to overcome their fear of math.
Yes, i think this course is beneficial to those with little or no calculus background.
Yes, there were many supports fur students in place especially with psets
Yes, it is super useful for anyone with not much of a background in maths.
Definitely! As long as you put in the effort, you'll come out of the class confident about introductory calculus.
